[[Cessnock, New South Wales|Cessnock]] | owner = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | format = [[Talk radio]] | website = [http://www.abc.net.au/newcastle/ http://www.abc.net.au/newcastle/ ] | }} '''1233 ABC Newcastle''' (call sign: '''2NC''') is an Australian radio station. It is the [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] station of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] local radio network, and is licensed to, and serving Newcastle and surrounding areas. It operates on the [[Amplitude modulation|AM]] band at 1233 [[kilohertz]]. Formerly known by its callsign 2NC, the NC in the callsign is short for '''''N'''''ew'''''c'''''astle, while the 2 represents the state of [[New South Wales]]. The station was established in 1930. ==History== 2NC was the very first regional radio station in Australia outside a capital city. It was set up by Adrian Jose. The first broadcast occurred 19 December 1930, and played the Newcastle Symphony Orchestra playing the [[William Tell Overture]]. [[James Fenton]] acting as the [[prime minister of Australia]] gave a speech. Local Newcastle content was limited to an hour a week and included news, market reports and church services.http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/03/07/2183117.htm The station was heard in New Zealand. Its original frequency was 1245 kHz or wavelength of 241 meters. The power was 2 kW with a modulation of 85%. The transmitting equipment was established by Keith Thow of [[Standard Telephones and Cables|STC]].{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19301231.2.27.5|newspaper=Evening Post|volume=CX|issue=155|date=31 December 1930|Page=4|title=2NC, Newcastle}} The transmitting antenna is at [[Beresfield, New South Wales|Beresfield]]. It was designed to have a range of 25 miles, covering a population of 200,000.{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19300918.2.165.3|newspaper=Evening Post|volume=CX|issue=69|date=18 September 1930|Page=23|title=Newcastle Relay Station}} In 1931 [[2YB]] in [[New Plymouth, New Zealand]] was interfering with 2NC causing a [[heterodyne]] whistle.{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?d&d=EP19310401.2.118.1|newspaper=Evening Post|volume=CXI|issue=77|date=1 April 1931|Page=19|title=Radio COntrol, The BBC Suggested As a Model}} Other early local content included the Newcastle Steel Works Band, the Newcastle Choral Society and the Newcastle Revellers. For a time in the early 2000's, the ABC Newcastle website included a 5 day-a-week 5 minute TV news bulletin dedicated to Newcastle, shot in the ABC NSW studio. ==Programs== Its programs are also heard on [[2UH|ABC Upper Hunter]], the ABC's station serving the [[Upper Hunter]]. ==Sports coverage== In addition to Grandstand's national coverage, 1233 ABC Newcastle and ABC Upper Hunter also broadcast [[Newcastle Knights]] rugby league and [[Newcastle Jets]] soccer games as well. ==Programs and presenters== (All other times taken up with news or non-local programs) ===Weekdays=== *Breakfast â Aaron Kearney, 5:30 AM to 7:45 AM *Mornings â Jill Emberson, 8:30 AM to 11:00 AM *Afternoons â Carol Duncan, 1:00 PM to 3:00 PM *Drive â Paul Bevan, 3:00 PM to 6:00 PM ===Weekends=== '''Saturday''' *Saturday Breakfast â Craig Hamilton, 6:00 AM to 10:00 AM *[[Treasure Hunter]] â Jenny Marchant, Saturday 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM '''Sunday''' *Sunday Morning Statewide â Helen Clare, 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM ==See also== *[[2UH|ABC Upper Hunter]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.abc.net.au/newcastle/] 1233 ABC Newcastle official website *[http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/03/07/2183117.htm] A history of the ABC in Newcastle {{Newcastle (NSW) Radio}} {{ABC Local Radio}} {{Coord|32.925959|S|151.757083|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1233 Abc Newcastle}} [[Category:Radio stations in Newcastle, New South Wales|2NC]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1930]] {{Australia-radio-station-stub}}
